Implement the following plan:

# Plan: Remove `[rustc]` section, promote `build_std`, add `rustflags` escape hatch

## Context

The `[rustc]` section currently has two fields: `build_std` (a cargo `-Z` flag, not a rustc flag) and `flags` (raw RUSTFLAGS passthrough). `build_std` deserves first-class treatment under `[cargo]` since it's a cargo flag that triggers `+nightly` and has a known set of valid crate names. `flags` becomes a top-level `rustflags` array — a simple escape hatch mirroring `RUSTFLAGS` semantics.

### Before → After

```toml
# Before
[rustc]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]
flags = ["-C", "some-thing"]

# After
[cargo]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]

rustflags = ["-C", "some-thing"]
```

## Changes

### 0. Chore setup — version bump, notes, todo
- Bump `Cargo.toml` version to `0.11.6-dev1`
- Add chores-5 entry for this work
- Move item to `## In Progress` in todo.md with reference to chore
- Commit as chore marker

### 1. `src/types.rs` — Restructure types
- Move `build_std: Vec<String>` from `RustcConfig` into `CargoConfig`
- Add `rustflags: Vec<String>` as a top-level field on `Spec` (with `#[serde(default)]`)
- Delete `RustcConfig` struct entirely
- Remove `rustc: RustcConfig` field from `Spec`

### 2. `src/cargo_build.rs` — Update spec application
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Change `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`
- In `requires_nightly()`: update `has_build_std` to read from `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Remove `let rustc = &spec.rustc;` binding

### 3. `src/testing.rs` — Update duplicate `requires_nightly()`
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`

### 4. `src/ts_cmd/edit.rs` — Update field registry
- Change `("rustc.build_std", FieldKind::Array)` → `("cargo.build_std", FieldKind::Array)`
- Change `("rustc.flags", FieldKind::Array)` → `("rustflags", FieldKind::Array)`
- Update all affected unit tests (validate_key, unset, set_table_value tests referencing rustc)

### 5. `src/ts_cmd/set.rs` — Update tests
- Rename `set_rustc_build_std` → `set_cargo_build_std`, change field to `"cargo.build_std"`
- Rename `set_rustc_flags` → `set_rustflags`, change field to `"rustflags"`
- Update assertions from `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`, `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`

### 6. `src/ts_cmd/unset.rs` — Update tests
- `unset_nested_field` test: change from `[rustc]` input to `[cargo]` with `build_std`; or use `rustflags` top-level field
- Update assertions accordingly

### 7. `src/tspec.rs` — Update tests
- `hash_empty_spec` / `hash_spec`: change `spec.rustc` references to new locations
- Update `RustcConfig` imports to removed

### 8. `tests/tspec_test.rs` — Update integration tests
- Remove `RustcConfig` import
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Change `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`

### 9. Documentation
- `README.md`: Update spec structure docs, field table, `ts set` examples
- `CLAUDE.md`: Update `[rustc]` line in Translation Spec Structure section

### 10. No spec file changes needed
- No existing `*.ts.toml` files have a `[rustc]` section

## Verification

```bash
tspec test -p tspec
tspec test -p tspec-build
tspec install --path .
tspec test -p tspec
tspec clippy
tspec fmt --check
```


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /home/wink/.claude/projects/-home-wink-data-prgs-rust-tspec/ed421e8d-c9e5-4da9-8b8f-6d6a19367cdf.jsonl

# Plan: Remove `[rustc]` section, promote `build_std`, add `rustflags` escape hatch

## Context

The `[rustc]` section currently has two fields: `build_std` (a cargo `-Z` flag, not a rustc flag) and `flags` (raw RUSTFLAGS passthrough). `build_std` deserves first-class treatment under `[cargo]` since it's a cargo flag that triggers `+nightly` and has a known set of valid crate names. `flags` becomes a top-level `rustflags` array — a simple escape hatch mirroring `RUSTFLAGS` semantics.

### Before → After

```toml
# Before
[rustc]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]
flags = ["-C", "some-thing"]

# After
[cargo]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]

rustflags = ["-C", "some-thing"]
```

## Changes

### 0. Chore setup — version bump, notes, todo
- Bump `Cargo.toml` version to `0.11.6-dev1`
- Add chores-5 entry for this work
- Move item to `## In Progress` in todo.md with reference to chore
- Commit as chore marker

### 1. `src/types.rs` — Restructure types
- Move `build_std: Vec<String>` from `RustcConfig` into `CargoConfig`
- Add `rustflags: Vec<String>` as a top-level field on `Spec` (with `#[serde(default)]`)
- Delete `RustcConfig` struct entirely
- Remove `rustc: RustcConfig` field from `Spec`

### 2. `src/cargo_build.rs` — Update spec application
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Change `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`
- In `requires_nightly()`: update `has_build_std` to read from `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Remove `let rustc = &spec.rustc;` binding

### 3. `src/testing.rs` — Update duplicate `requires_nightly()`
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`

### 4. `src/ts_cmd/edit.rs` — Update field registry
- Change `("rustc.build_std", FieldKind::Array)` → `("cargo.build_std", FieldKind::Array)`
- Change `("rustc.flags", FieldKind::Array)` → `("rustflags", FieldKind::Array)`
- Update all affected unit tests (validate_key, unset, set_table_value tests referencing rustc)

### 5. `src/ts_cmd/set.rs` — Update tests
- Rename `set_rustc_build_std` → `set_cargo_build_std`, change field to `"cargo.build_std"`
- Rename `set_rustc_flags` → `set_rustflags`, change field to `"rustflags"`
- Update assertions from `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`, `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`

### 6. `src/ts_cmd/unset.rs` — Update tests
- `unset_nested_field` test: change from `[rustc]` input to `[cargo]` with `build_std`; or use `rustflags` top-level field
- Update assertions accordingly

### 7. `src/tspec.rs` — Update tests
- `hash_empty_spec` / `hash_spec`: change `spec.rustc` references to new locations
- Update `RustcConfig` imports to removed

### 8. `tests/tspec_test.rs` — Update integration tests
- Remove `RustcConfig` import
- Change `spec.rustc.build_std` → `spec.cargo.build_std`
- Change `spec.rustc.flags` → `spec.rustflags`

### 9. Documentation
- `README.md`: Update spec structure docs, field table, `ts set` examples
- `CLAUDE.md`: Update `[rustc]` line in Translation Spec Structure section

### 10. No spec file changes needed
- No existing `*.ts.toml` files have a `[rustc]` section

## Verification

```bash
tspec test -p tspec
tspec test -p tspec-build
tspec install --path .
tspec test -p tspec
tspec clippy
tspec fmt --check
```

[workspace]
members = ["tspec-build"]

[package]
name = "tspec"
version = "0.11.5"
edition = "2024"
description = "Translation spec based build system"
authors = ["Wink Saville <wink@saville.com>, Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>"]
license = "MIT, Apache-2.0"
repository = "https://github.com/wink/tspec"
exclude = [".claude/", "notes/"]

[dependencies]
clap = { version = "4", features = ["derive"] }
serde = { version = "1", features = ["derive"] }
toml = "0.8"
toml_edit = "0.22"
anyhow = "1"
sha2 = "0.10"
hex = "0.4"
cargo_metadata = "0.19"
glob = "0.3"

[dev-dependencies]

1→use serde::{Deserialize, Serialize};
     2→use std::collections::BTreeMap;
     3→use std::fmt;
     4→use std::path::PathBuf;
     5→
     6→use crate::options::{PanicMode, StripMode};
     7→
     8→/// Build profile - mutually exclusive
     9→#[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    10→#[serde(rename_all = "lowercase")]
    11→pub enum Profile {
    12→    Debug,
    13→    Release,
    14→}
    15→
    16→/// A value in the `[cargo.config_key_value]` table.
    17→/// Uses `#[serde(untagged)]` so TOML bools/ints/strings are deserialized naturally.
    18→/// We avoid `toml::Value` because it contains `Float(f64)` which doesn't implement `Eq`.
    19→#[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    20→#[serde(untagged)]
    21→pub enum ConfigValue {
    22→    Bool(bool),
    23→    Integer(i64),
    24→    String(String),
    25→}
    26→
    27→impl fmt::Display for ConfigValue {
    28→    fn fmt(&self, f: &mut fmt::Formatter<'_>) -> fmt::Result {
    29→        match self {
    30→            ConfigValue::Bool(b) => write!(f, "{}", b),
    31→            ConfigValue::Integer(n) => write!(f, "{}", n),
    32→            ConfigValue::String(s) => write!(f, "\"{}\"", s),
    33→        }
    34→    }
    35→}
    36→
    37→/// Cargo-specific configuration (flat struct)
    38→#[derive(Debug, Clone, Default, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    39→pub struct CargoConfig {
    40→    /// Build profile (debug or release)
    41→    pub profile: Option<Profile>,
    42→    /// Target triple (e.g., "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl")
    43→    pub target_triple: Option<String>,
    44→    /// Custom target JSON file path
    45→    pub target_json: Option<PathBuf>,
    46→    /// Nightly-only -Z flags (e.g., ["panic-immediate-abort"])
    47→    #[serde(default)]
    48→    pub unstable: Vec<String>,
    49→    /// Custom target directory subdirectory for per-spec isolation.
    50→    /// Supports `{name}` (spec filename sans .ts.toml) and `{hash}` (8-char content hash).
    51→    pub target_dir: Option<String>,
    52→    /// Key-value pairs passed as `--config 'KEY=VALUE'` to cargo.
    53→    /// Each entry becomes a separate `--config` arg.
    54→    #[serde(default)]
    55→    pub config_key_value: BTreeMap<String, ConfigValue>,
    56→}
    57→
    58→/// Rustc codegen and compilation configuration (flat struct)
    59→#[derive(Debug, Clone, Default, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    60→pub struct RustcConfig {
    61→    /// Crates to rebuild with -Z build-std (nightly only)
    62→    #[serde(default)]
    63→    pub build_std: Vec<String>,
    64→    /// Raw flags passed through
    65→    #[serde(default)]
    66→    pub flags: Vec<String>,
    67→}
    68→
    69→/// Version script configuration for symbol visibility
    70→#[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    71→pub struct VersionScript {
    72→    /// Symbols to keep global (e.g., ["_start"])
    73→    pub global: Vec<String>,
    74→    /// Pattern for local symbols (typically "*")
    75→    #[serde(default = "default_local")]
    76→    pub local: String,
    77→}
    78→
    79→fn default_local() -> String {
    80→    "*".to_string()
    81→}
    82→
    83→/// Linker configuration (flat struct)
    84→#[derive(Debug, Clone, Default, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    85→pub struct LinkerConfig {
    86→    /// Linker arguments (e.g., ["-static", "-nostdlib"])
    87→    #[serde(default)]
    88→    pub args: Vec<String>,
    89→    /// Version script for symbol visibility (enables --gc-sections optimization)
    90→    pub version_script: Option<VersionScript>,
    91→}
    92→
    93→/// A translation spec
    94→#[derive(Debug, Clone, Default, PartialEq, Eq, Serialize, Deserialize)]
    95→pub struct Spec {
    96→    /// High-level panic mode (sets both cargo -Z and rustc -C flags)
    97→    pub panic: Option<PanicMode>,
    98→
    99→    /// High-level strip mode (sets rustc -C strip=)
   100→    pub strip: Option<StripMode>,
   101→
   102→    #[serde(default)]
   103→    pub cargo: CargoConfig,
   104→    #[serde(default)]
   105→    pub rustc: RustcConfig,
   106→    #[serde(default)]
   107→    pub linker: LinkerConfig,
   108→}
   109→
   110→#[cfg(test)]
   111→mod tests {
   112→    use super::*;
   113→
   114→    #[test]
   115→    fn spec_default_is_empty() {
   116→        let spec = Spec::default();
   117→        assert_eq!(spec.cargo, CargoConfig::default());
   118→        assert_eq!(spec.rustc, RustcConfig::default());
   119→        assert_eq!(spec.linker, LinkerConfig::default());
   120→    }
   121→}
   122→

# Todo

## In Progress

## Todo
- Refactor `build_package`, `test_package`, `plain_cargo_build_release` into a unified cargo runner [30]
- Add a permanent test workspace for integration testing (external repo or embedded?)
- Add benchmark support, especially cold-start vs hot-start build timing
- Add database for collecting build data over time (could store tspecs, possibly replace backup/restore)
- Investigate `-static` vs `dynamic-linking=false` size difference (partially explained); note: glibc + `-static` segfaults (glibc not designed for static linking), consider musl for static builds [11]
- Improve `classify_crate` - using name alone is brittle [4]

## Done

See older [done.md](done.md)

- Add glob support for `-t` flag on build, run, test commands [29]
- Remove `rustc.opt_level`, `rustc.lto`, `rustc.codegen_units` — migrate to `config_key_value`; fix tspec-build test race condition [28]
- Add `[cargo.config_key_value]` for `--config KEY=VALUE` args [25],[26],[27]

[28]: chores-5.md#20260216---remove-rustcopt_level-rustclto-rustccodegen_units--migrate-to-config_key_value

[4]: chores-1.md#improve-classify_crate
[11]: chores-1.md#investigate--static-vs-dynamic-linkingfalse-size-difference
[25]: chores-4.md#20260215---design-profile-support-and-tspec-section-scoping
[26]: chores-4.md#20260216---design-passing-tspec-fields-via-buildrs-vs-cargo---config
[27]: chores-4.md#20260216---implement-cargoconfig_key_value-support

content.content:
1→# Chores-5
     2→
     3→## 20260216 - Future: config_key_value and rustc field migration
     4→
     5→### Context
     6→
     7→`[cargo.config_key_value]` is now implemented, providing a general-purpose mechanism for
     8→passing `--config KEY=VALUE` args to cargo. This enables per-package profile overrides
     9→without bleeding settings through RUSTFLAGS.
    10→
    11→### Open questions
    12→
    13→- **Auto-scoping:** Should tspec automatically scope config keys with
    14→  `profile.*.package.<name>` so users don't have to write the full path? Currently users
    15→  write exact cargo config keys — no magic.
    16→- **`[rustc]` field migration:** Several `[rustc]` fields (`opt_level`, `lto`,
    17→  `codegen_units`) duplicate what cargo profiles express. These could migrate to
    18→  `config_key_value` entries, but that's a separate follow-up. The existing fields work
    19→  fine via RUSTFLAGS for now.
    20→- **High-level fields (`panic`, `strip`):** These expand to both cargo and rustc flags.
    21→  Moving them to `config_key_value` would lose the multi-flag expansion. They likely stay
    22→  as top-level fields.
    23→
    24→### Finding: RUSTFLAGS vs --config produce same-size but non-identical binaries
    25→
    26→Tested with `tspec-build` library crate using two equivalent specs:
    27→- `tspec.opt.ts.toml` — uses `rustc.opt_level = "z"` and `rustc.codegen_units = 1` (RUSTFLAGS)
    28→- `tspec.opt-kv.ts.toml` — uses `[cargo.config_key_value]` with equivalent `--config` args
    29→
    30→Results:
    31→- Binary sizes: **identical** (1,117,880 bytes both)
    32→- Binary content: **differs** (~72K of ~1.1M bytes, ~6.5%)
    33→- Changing `target_dir` alone does NOT cause differences (confirmed byte-identical)
    34→- The difference is solely from RUSTFLAGS `-C opt-level=z` vs `--config 'profile.release.opt-level="z"'`
    35→
    36→The two mechanisms produce equivalently optimized but not bit-identical binaries.
    37→Cause is unclear — possibly different flag ordering, different cargo-internal rustc
    38→invocation paths, or non-deterministic codegen. Not a practical concern since the
    39→optimization effect is the same.
    40→
    41→### Status
    42→
    43→Done — see next section.
    44→
    45→## 20260216 - Add glob support for `-t` flag on build, run, test
    46→
    47→### Context
    48→
    49→The compare command already supported glob patterns for `-t` and `-w`/`--workspace` for
    50→all-packages mode. Build, run, and test commands only accepted a single `-t` value and
    51→had no `-w` flag.
    52→
    53→### Changes
    54→
    55→- Changed `-t`/`--tspec` from `Option<String>` to `Vec<String>` with `num_args=1..`
    56→  on build, run, and test commands, matching compare's pattern
    57→- When multiple specs match a glob, the operation executes once per spec in sequence
    58→- Block `-t` in all-packages mode (`-w`) with a clear error
    59→- Added clap parsing tests to all three commands
    60→
    61→### Status
    62→
    63→Done — released in v0.11.3.
    64→
    65→## 20260216 - Remove `rustc.opt_level`, `rustc.lto`, `rustc.codegen_units` — migrate to `config_key_value`
    66→
    67→### Context
    68→
    69→These three `[rustc]` fields duplicate what `[cargo.config_key_value]` can express via
    70→`cargo --config`. We confirmed they produce identical binary sizes. Since we're the only
    71→users, we can remove them without deprecation. `[rustc]` section stays with `build_std`
    72→and `flags`.
    73→
    74→### Changes
    75→
    76→1. **types.rs:** Deleted `OptLevel` enum; removed `opt_level`, `lto`, `codegen_units`
    77→   from `RustcConfig` (kept `build_std`, `flags`)
    78→2. **cargo_build.rs:** Removed RUSTFLAGS generation for the three fields; removed
    79→   `OptLevel` import
    80→3. **ts_cmd/edit.rs:** Removed 3 `FIELD_REGISTRY` entries, 3 `validate_value` arms,
    81→   `parse_scalar_value` special cases; updated/deleted affected unit tests
    82→4. **ts_cmd/set.rs:** Deleted `set_rustc_lto`, `set_rustc_opt_level`, `set_codegen_units` tests
    83→5. **ts_cmd/unset.rs:** Rewrote `unset_nested_field` test to use `rustc.build_std`/`flags`
    84→6. **cmd/ts.rs:** Changed `"rustc.lto"` doc examples to `"cargo.profile"`
    85→7. **Spec files:** Migrated `opt_level`/`codegen_units` to `[cargo.config_key_value]`
    86→   in `tspec.release.ts.toml`, `tspec.musl.ts.toml`, `tspec-build/tspec.opt.ts.toml`
    87→8. **Test fixtures:** Migrated `tests/data/minimal.toml`; updated `tests/tspec_test.rs`
    88→   `load_minimal_spec` to check `config_key_value` instead of `rustc.opt_level`
    89→
    90→### Status
    91→
    92→Done.
    93→
    94→## 20260217 - Fix: test race condition with `std::env::set_var` / `remove_var`
    95→
    96→### Problem
    97→
    98→`tspec test` intermittently failed on the `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` test in
    99→`tspec-build`. The failure was not reproducible when running `tspec test -p tspec-build`
   100→alone — only when both packages ran together via `tspec test`.
   101→
   102→### Root cause
   103→
   104→Rust runs tests in parallel on multiple threads within the same process.
   105→`std::env::set_var()` and `std::env::remove_var()` are process-wide — they mutate
   106→shared global state. Two tests that manipulate the same env var (`TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`)
   107→race each other:
   108→
   109→- `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` — sets `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, calls function, removes it
   110→- `resolve_spec_path_none_without_env` — removes `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, asserts `None`
   111→
   112→If the "without" test runs between the set and remove of the "with" test, it sees the
   113→var and fails. Or vice versa. This is a well-known Rust testing pitfall — `set_var` is
   114→marked `unsafe` in Rust 2024 edition precisely because of this.
   115→
   116→### Solutions considered
   117→

file.content:
# Chores-5

## 20260216 - Future: config_key_value and rustc field migration

### Context

`[cargo.config_key_value]` is now implemented, providing a general-purpose mechanism for
passing `--config KEY=VALUE` args to cargo. This enables per-package profile overrides
without bleeding settings through RUSTFLAGS.

### Open questions

- **Auto-scoping:** Should tspec automatically scope config keys with
  `profile.*.package.<name>` so users don't have to write the full path? Currently users
  write exact cargo config keys — no magic.
- **`[rustc]` field migration:** Several `[rustc]` fields (`opt_level`, `lto`,
  `codegen_units`) duplicate what cargo profiles express. These could migrate to
  `config_key_value` entries, but that's a separate follow-up. The existing fields work
  fine via RUSTFLAGS for now.
- **High-level fields (`panic`, `strip`):** These expand to both cargo and rustc flags.
  Moving them to `config_key_value` would lose the multi-flag expansion. They likely stay
  as top-level fields.

### Finding: RUSTFLAGS vs --config produce same-size but non-identical binaries

Tested with `tspec-build` library crate using two equivalent specs:
- `tspec.opt.ts.toml` — uses `rustc.opt_level = "z"` and `rustc.codegen_units = 1` (RUSTFLAGS)
- `tspec.opt-kv.ts.toml` — uses `[cargo.config_key_value]` with equivalent `--config` args

Results:
- Binary sizes: **identical** (1,117,880 bytes both)
- Binary content: **differs** (~72K of ~1.1M bytes, ~6.5%)
- Changing `target_dir` alone does NOT cause differences (confirmed byte-identical)
- The difference is solely from RUSTFLAGS `-C opt-level=z` vs `--config 'profile.release.opt-level="z"'`

The two mechanisms produce equivalently optimized but not bit-identical binaries.
Cause is unclear — possibly different flag ordering, different cargo-internal rustc
invocation paths, or non-deterministic codegen. Not a practical concern since the
optimization effect is the same.

### Status

Done — see next section.

## 20260216 - Add glob support for `-t` flag on build, run, test

### Context

The compare command already supported glob patterns for `-t` and `-w`/`--workspace` for
all-packages mode. Build, run, and test commands only accepted a single `-t` value and
had no `-w` flag.

### Changes

- Changed `-t`/`--tspec` from `Option<String>` to `Vec<String>` with `num_args=1..`
  on build, run, and test commands, matching compare's pattern
- When multiple specs match a glob, the operation executes once per spec in sequence
- Block `-t` in all-packages mode (`-w`) with a clear error
- Added clap parsing tests to all three commands

### Status

Done — released in v0.11.3.

## 20260216 - Remove `rustc.opt_level`, `rustc.lto`, `rustc.codegen_units` — migrate to `config_key_value`

### Context

These three `[rustc]` fields duplicate what `[cargo.config_key_value]` can express via
`cargo --config`. We confirmed they produce identical binary sizes. Since we're the only
users, we can remove them without deprecation. `[rustc]` section stays with `build_std`
and `flags`.

### Changes

1. **types.rs:** Deleted `OptLevel` enum; removed `opt_level`, `lto`, `codegen_units`
   from `RustcConfig` (kept `build_std`, `flags`)
2. **cargo_build.rs:** Removed RUSTFLAGS generation for the three fields; removed
   `OptLevel` import
3. **ts_cmd/edit.rs:** Removed 3 `FIELD_REGISTRY` entries, 3 `validate_value` arms,
   `parse_scalar_value` special cases; updated/deleted affected unit tests
4. **ts_cmd/set.rs:** Deleted `set_rustc_lto`, `set_rustc_opt_level`, `set_codegen_units` tests
5. **ts_cmd/unset.rs:** Rewrote `unset_nested_field` test to use `rustc.build_std`/`flags`
6. **cmd/ts.rs:** Changed `"rustc.lto"` doc examples to `"cargo.profile"`
7. **Spec files:** Migrated `opt_level`/`codegen_units` to `[cargo.config_key_value]`
   in `tspec.release.ts.toml`, `tspec.musl.ts.toml`, `tspec-build/tspec.opt.ts.toml`
8. **Test fixtures:** Migrated `tests/data/minimal.toml`; updated `tests/tspec_test.rs`
   `load_minimal_spec` to check `config_key_value` instead of `rustc.opt_level`

### Status

Done.

## 20260217 - Fix: test race condition with `std::env::set_var` / `remove_var`

### Problem

`tspec test` intermittently failed on the `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` test in
`tspec-build`. The failure was not reproducible when running `tspec test -p tspec-build`
alone — only when both packages ran together via `tspec test`.

### Root cause

Rust runs tests in parallel on multiple threads within the same process.
`std::env::set_var()` and `std::env::remove_var()` are process-wide — they mutate
shared global state. Two tests that manipulate the same env var (`TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`)
race each other:

- `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` — sets `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, calls function, removes it
- `resolve_spec_path_none_without_env` — removes `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, asserts `None`

If the "without" test runs between the set and remove of the "with" test, it sees the
var and fails. Or vice versa. This is a well-known Rust testing pitfall — `set_var` is
marked `unsafe` in Rust 2024 edition precisely because of this.

### Solutions considered

1. **Static Mutex** — wrap env-var tests so they run one at a time. Works but easy to
   forget for new tests, and doesn't prevent the class of bug.
2. **`serial_test` crate** — adds `#[serial]` attribute. Clean syntax but adds a
   dependency and still relies on developers remembering to annotate.
3. **`--test-threads=1`** — heavy-handed, slows down all tests.
4. **`_inner` pattern (chosen)** — extract a pure function that takes env values as
   parameters. The public function reads env vars and delegates. Tests call `_inner`
   directly with their own values — no shared state, no race, impossible to flake.
5. **Temp directory copies (for future integration tests)** — when tests need to
   modify real package layouts (Cargo.toml, spec files, source), each test copies
   the fixture into its own `tempdir()`. No shared filesystem state, parallel-safe,
   cleanup is automatic via `Drop`.

### Principle

Push side effects (env var reads, file I/O) to the edges. Keep core logic pure and
parameterized. Tests exercise the logic without touching the real world. For filesystem
mutations, each test owns a private copy.

### Changes

- **tspec-build/src/lib.rs:** Split `resolve_spec_path` into a thin env-reading wrapper
  and `resolve_spec_path_inner` that takes `manifest_dir` and `env_spec_file` as
  `Option<&str>` parameters. Rewrote all three `resolve_spec_path_*` tests and
  `emit_from_reads_spec_file` to call `_inner` directly — no `set_var`/`remove_var`.

### Status

Done.

## 20260217 - Refactor cargo runner functions into unified fn

### Context

Three functions share nearly identical structure:
- `cargo_build::build_package` — builds with optional spec, returns `BuildResult`
- `testing::test_package` — tests with optional spec, returns `()`
- `cargo_build::plain_cargo_build_release` — builds without spec, returns `BuildResult`

They all follow the same skeleton: find workspace/package/tspec, clean stale build.rs,
optionally load spec, generate build.rs if needed, construct `Command` (with optional
`+nightly`), run, clean up, warn about stale files.

`plain_cargo_build_release` is just `build_package` with `tspec=None` and `release=true`.
`test_package` differs only in the subcommand (`test` vs `build`) and has its own
duplicate `requires_nightly()` function in `testing.rs`.

### Plan

Unify into a single `run_cargo` function that takes the subcommand as a parameter.
`plain_cargo_build_release` becomes a thin call. `test_package` becomes a wrapper that
calls the unified function and discards `BuildResult`. The duplicate `requires_nightly()`
in `testing.rs` is eliminated.

### Differences to reconcile

| Aspect | `build_package` | `test_package` | `plain_cargo_build_release` |
|---|---|---|---|
| Subcommand | `build` | `test` | `build` |
| Spec | optional | optional | never |
| Returns | `BuildResult` | `()` | `BuildResult` |
| `+nightly` | via `build_cargo_command()` | inlined `requires_nightly()` | no (no spec) |
| build.rs gen | yes (checks bin target) | yes (no bin check) | no |

### Status

Not started.

## 20260217 - Remove `[rustc]` section, promote `build_std`, add `rustflags`

### Context

The `[rustc]` section has two remaining fields: `build_std` (actually a cargo `-Z` flag,
not a rustc flag) and `flags` (raw RUSTFLAGS passthrough). `build_std` belongs under
`[cargo]` since it triggers `+nightly` and `-Z build-std=...`. `flags` becomes a
top-level `rustflags` array — a simple escape hatch mirroring `RUSTFLAGS` semantics.

### Before → After

```toml
# Before
[rustc]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]
flags = ["-C", "some-thing"]

# After
[cargo]
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]

rustflags = ["-C", "some-thing"]
```

### Changes

1. **types.rs:** Move `build_std` to `CargoConfig`, add `rustflags` to `Spec`, delete `RustcConfig`
2. **cargo_build.rs:** Update all `spec.rustc` references to new locations
3. **testing.rs:** Update duplicate `requires_nightly()` to use `spec.cargo.build_std`
4. **ts_cmd/edit.rs:** Update field registry and tests
5. **ts_cmd/set.rs, unset.rs:** Update tests
6. **tspec.rs:** Update tests (remove `RustcConfig` references)
7. **tests/tspec_test.rs:** Update integration tests
8. **README.md, CLAUDE.md:** Update documentation

### Status

In progress.

## 20260216 - Add glob support for `-t` flag on build, run, test

### Context

The compare command already supported glob patterns for `-t` and `-w`/`--workspace` for
all-packages mode. Build, run, and test commands only accepted a single `-t` value and
had no `-w` flag.

### Changes

- Changed `-t`/`--tspec` from `Option<String>` to `Vec<String>` with `num_args=1..`
  on build, run, and test commands, matching compare's pattern
- When multiple specs match a glob, the operation executes once per spec in sequence
- Block `-t` in all-packages mode (`-w`) with a clear error
- Added clap parsing tests to all three commands

### Status

Done — released in v0.11.3.

## 20260216 - Remove `rustc.opt_level`, `rustc.lto`, `rustc.codegen_units` — migrate to `config_key_value`

### Context

These three `[rustc]` fields duplicate what `[cargo.config_key_value]` can express via
`cargo --config`. We confirmed they produce identical binary sizes. Since we're the only
users, we can remove them without deprecation. `[rustc]` section stays with `build_std`
and `flags`.

### Changes

1. **types.rs:** Deleted `OptLevel` enum; removed `opt_level`, `lto`, `codegen_units`
   from `RustcConfig` (kept `build_std`, `flags`)
2. **cargo_build.rs:** Removed RUSTFLAGS generation for the three fields; removed
   `OptLevel` import
3. **ts_cmd/edit.rs:** Removed 3 `FIELD_REGISTRY` entries, 3 `validate_value` arms,
   `parse_scalar_value` special cases; updated/deleted affected unit tests
4. **ts_cmd/set.rs:** Deleted `set_rustc_lto`, `set_rustc_opt_level`, `set_codegen_units` tests
5. **ts_cmd/unset.rs:** Rewrote `unset_nested_field` test to use `rustc.build_std`/`flags`
6. **cmd/ts.rs:** Changed `"rustc.lto"` doc examples to `"cargo.profile"`
7. **Spec files:** Migrated `opt_level`/`codegen_units` to `[cargo.config_key_value]`
   in `tspec.release.ts.toml`, `tspec.musl.ts.toml`, `tspec-build/tspec.opt.ts.toml`
8. **Test fixtures:** Migrated `tests/data/minimal.toml`; updated `tests/tspec_test.rs`
   `load_minimal_spec` to check `config_key_value` instead of `rustc.opt_level`

### Status

Done.

## 20260217 - Fix: test race condition with `std::env::set_var` / `remove_var`

### Problem

`tspec test` intermittently failed on the `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` test in
`tspec-build`. The failure was not reproducible when running `tspec test -p tspec-build`
alone — only when both packages ran together via `tspec test`.

### Root cause

Rust runs tests in parallel on multiple threads within the same process.
`std::env::set_var()` and `std::env::remove_var()` are process-wide — they mutate
shared global state. Two tests that manipulate the same env var (`TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`)
race each other:

- `resolve_spec_path_none_with_env` — sets `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, calls function, removes it
- `resolve_spec_path_none_without_env` — removes `TSPEC_SPEC_FILE`, asserts `None`

If the "without" test runs between the set and remove of the "with" test, it sees the
var and fails. Or vice versa. This is a well-known Rust testing pitfall — `set_var` is
marked `unsafe` in Rust 2024 edition precisely because of this.

### Solutions considered

1. **Static Mutex** — wrap env-var tests so they run one at a time. Works but easy to
   forget for new tests, and doesn't prevent the class of bug.
2. **`serial_test` crate** — adds `#[serial]` attribute. Clean syntax but adds a
   dependency and still relies on developers remembering to annotate.
3. **`--test-threads=1`** — heavy-handed, slows down all tests.
4. **`_inner` pattern (chosen)** — extract a pure function that takes env values as
   parameters. The public function reads env vars and delegates. Tests call `_inner`
   directly with their own values — no shared state, no race, impossible to flake.
5. **Temp directory copies (for future integration tests)** — when tests need to
   modify real package layouts (Cargo.toml, spec files, source), each test copies
   the fixture into its own `tempdir()`. No shared filesystem state, parallel-safe,
   cleanup is automatic via `Drop`.

### Principle

Push side effects (env var reads, file I/O) to the edges. Keep core logic pure and
parameterized. Tests exercise the logic without touching the real world. For filesystem
mutations, each test owns a private copy.

### Changes

- **tspec-build/src/lib.rs:** Split `resolve_spec_path` into a thin env-reading wrapper
  and `resolve_spec_path_inner` that takes `manifest_dir` and `env_spec_file` as
  `Option<&str>` parameters. Rewrote all three `resolve_spec_path_*` tests and
  `emit_from_reads_spec_file` to call `_inner` directly — no `set_var`/`remove_var`.

### Status

Done.

## 20260217 - Refactor cargo runner functions into unified fn

### Context

Three functions share nearly identical structure:
- `cargo_build::build_package` — builds with optional spec, returns `BuildResult`
- `testing::test_package` — tests with optional spec, returns `()`
- `cargo_build::plain_cargo_build_release` — builds without spec, returns `BuildResult`

They all follow the same skeleton: find workspace/package/tspec, clean stale build.rs,
optionally load spec, generate build.rs if needed, construct `Command` (with optional
`+nightly`), run, clean up, warn about stale files.

`plain_cargo_build_release` is just `build_package` with `tspec=None` and `release=true`.
`test_package` differs only in the subcommand (`test` vs `build`) and has its own
duplicate `requires_nightly()` function in `testing.rs`.

### Plan

Unify into a single `run_cargo` function that takes the subcommand as a parameter.
`plain_cargo_build_release` becomes a thin call. `test_package` becomes a wrapper that
calls the unified function and discards `BuildResult`. The duplicate `requires_nightly()`
in `testing.rs` is eliminated.

### Differences to reconcile

| Aspect | `build_package` | `test_package` | `plain_cargo_build_release` |
|---|---|---|---|
| Subcommand | `build` | `test` | `build` |
| Spec | optional | optional | never |
| Returns | `BuildResult` | `()` | `BuildResult` |
| `+nightly` | via `build_cargo_command()` | inlined `requires_nightly()` | no (no spec) |
| build.rs gen | yes (checks bin target) | yes (no bin check) | no |

### Status

Not started.

content.content:
1→# tspec - Translation Spec Build System
     2→
     3→A spec-driven build system for Rust that wraps cargo with configurable target triples, compiler flags, and linker options. Each tspec applies to a Cargo **package** — the unit with a `Cargo.toml`. If different crates need different compilation settings, they should be in separate packages.
     4→
     5→**Status:** Active development. Works with both workspaces and single-package projects, Plain Old Packages (POPs).
     6→
     7→## Installation
     8→
     9→```bash
    10→cargo install --path .
    11→```
    12→
    13→Or run directly:
    14→```bash
    15→cargo run -- build
    16→```
    17→
    18→## Usage
    19→
    20→```bash
    21→tspec build                                # Build current package (or all in workspace) with tspec.ts.toml if present
    22→tspec build -p myapp                       # Build specific package with tspec.ts.toml if present
    23→tspec build myapp                          # Same, using positional argument
    24→tspec build .                              # Build the package in current directory
    25→tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt          # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
    26→tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt.ts.toml  # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
    27→tspec build -p myapp -r -s                 # Build release, strip symbols with tspec.ts.toml if present
    28→tspec run -p myapp                         # Build and run with tspec.ts.toml if present
    29→tspec test -p myapp                        # Build and test with tspec.ts.toml if present
    30→tspec build -w                             # Build all packages (even from inside a package dir)
    31→tspec compare -p myapp                     # Compare binary sizes for a package
    32→tspec compare -p myapp -t *.ts.toml        # Compare using shell-expanded glob
    33→tspec compare                              # Compare all packages (workspace mode)
    34→tspec compare -w                           # Force workspace mode from inside a package
    35→tspec compare -w -f                        # Workspace mode, stop on first failure
    36→```
    37→
    38→The `-p` flag or positional argument specifies a package by name or path (defaults to current directory if in a package, otherwise all packages). Paths like `.` are resolved to the actual cargo package name. At a pure workspace root (no `[package]`), `.` means "all packages."
    39→Use `-w, --workspace` to force all-packages mode even when inside a package directory.
    40→The `-t` flag selects a tspec file; if omitted and `tspec.ts.toml` exists, it's used automatically.
    41→
    42→**Note on `cmd` vs `cmd .`:** For passthrough commands (clean, clippy, fmt), `tspec cmd` passes no `-p` to cargo (operates on everything), while `tspec cmd .` resolves to `cargo cmd -p <name>` (package-specific). The difference is most visible with `clean`: `cargo clean` removes all of target/ while `cargo clean -p <name>` leaves shared metadata files. This matches cargo's own behavior. Use `tspec clean` or `tspec clean -w` for a full clean.
    43→
    44→## tspec Files
    45→
    46→Translation specs are TOML files (conventionally `*.ts.toml`) that configure builds:
    47→
    48→```toml
    49→# tspec.ts.toml - all supported fields shown
    50→
    51→# Top-level high-level options (expand to lower-level cargo/rustc flags)
    52→panic = "abort"                            # "unwind" (default), "abort", "immediate-abort" (nightly)
    53→strip = "symbols"                          # "none" (default), "debuginfo", "symbols"
    54→
    55→[cargo]
    56→profile = "release"                        # "debug" (default), "release"
    57→target_triple = "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl"
    58→target_json = "path/to/custom-target.json" # custom target spec (auto-adds -Z json-target-spec)
    59→unstable = ["panic-immediate-abort"]       # -Z flags (nightly only)
    60→target_dir = "{name}"                      # per-spec target dir; supports {name} and {hash} placeholders
    61→
    62→[rustc]
    63→opt_level = "z"                            # "0", "1", "2", "3", "s", "z"
    64→panic = "abort"                            # "abort", "unwind", "immediate-abort" (prefer top-level panic)
    65→lto = true
    66→codegen_units = 1
    67→build_std = ["core", "alloc"]              # crates to rebuild with -Z build-std (nightly)
    68→flags = ["-C", "relocation-model=static"]  # raw rustc flags passed through
    69→
    70→[linker]
    71→args = ["-static", "-nostartfiles"]
    72→
    73→[linker.version_script]                    # symbol visibility control (enables --gc-sections)
    74→global = ["_start"]                        # symbols to keep
    75→local = "*"                                # default: "*" (hide everything else)
    76→```
    77→
    78→The top-level `panic` sets both cargo `-Z` and rustc `-C` flags automatically. If both
    79→top-level `panic` and `rustc.panic` are set, both are applied (prefer one or the other).
    80→
    81→### Key Concepts
    82→
    83→- **One tspec per package** - A tspec applies to all crates (targets) within a Cargo package. For per-crate control, use separate packages in a workspace.
    84→- **tspec.ts.toml is optional** - Packages without one get plain `cargo build/test`
    85→- **Generated build.rs** - tspec generates temporary build.rs for scoped linker flags
    86→- **Spec comparison** - Compare binary sizes across different specs; always shows both `cargo --release` and `cargo --release-strip` baselines. Supports `-w` for all-packages mode — per-package tables are collected and printed together at the end. With a single package, only its comparison table is shown
    87→
    88→### How Linker Flags Work
    89→
    90→tspec generates a temporary `build.rs` to apply linker flags with binary-scoped directives:
    91→
    92→```rust
    93→// Generated by tspec - deleted after build
    94→fn main() {
    95→    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-static");
    96→    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-nostdlib");
    97→}
    98→```
    99→
   100→This is necessary because RUSTFLAGS affects ALL compilations (including dependency
   101→build scripts), causing crashes with flags like `-nostartfiles`. The generated
   102→build.rs scopes flags to just the binary.
   103→
   104→## tspec Management (ts subcommand)
   105→
   106→Manage spec files without manual TOML editing. All commands that modify files preserve comments and formatting.
   107→
   108→| Command | Description |
   109→|---------|-------------|
   110→| `ts list` | List tspec files found in the workspace or a specific package |
   111→| `ts show` | Display the TOML contents of a tspec file |
   112→| `ts hash` | Print the content hash (used in backup filenames) of a tspec |
   113→| `ts new` | Create a new tspec with defaults, or copy an existing one with `-f` (byte-for-byte) |
   114→| `ts set` | Set a scalar value or replace an entire array |
   115→| `ts unset` | Remove a field (scalar or array) from a tspec entirely |
   116→| `ts add` | Add items to an array field (append or insert at position) |
   117→| `ts remove` | Remove items from an array field (by value or by index) |
   118→| `ts backup` | Create a versioned backup copy (`name-NNN-hash.ts.toml`) |
   119→| `ts restore` | Restore a tspec by copying a versioned backup back to its original name |
   120→
   121→```bash
   122→# List / show / hash
   123→tspec ts list                            # List all tspec files
   124→tspec ts list -p myapp                   # List tspec files for a package
   125→tspec ts show -p myapp                   # Show all tspec contents
   126→tspec ts show -p myapp -t tspec-opt      # Show specific tspec-opt.ts.toml
   127→tspec ts hash -p myapp                   # Show content hash of tspec.ts.toml
   128→
   129→# Create new tspec files
   130→tspec ts new -p myapp                    # Create tspec.ts.toml with defaults
   131→tspec ts new experiment -p myapp         # Create experiment.ts.toml
   132→tspec ts new opt2 -p myapp -f tspec-opt  # Copy from existing spec (byte-for-byte)
   133→
   134→# Set scalar values
   135→tspec ts set strip symbols -p myapp              # Set a scalar field
   136→tspec ts set rustc.lto true -t tspec-opt         # Set in a specific tspec
   137→tspec ts set cargo.profile release               # No quoting needed
   138→
   139→# Set (replace) entire arrays — each element is a separate arg
   140→tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib        # Replace array
   141→tspec ts set rustc.build_std core alloc           # Replace array
   142→
   143→# Add items to arrays (append by default)
   144→tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections        # Append one item
   145→tspec ts add linker.args -nostdlib -pie            # Append multiple items
   146→tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles        # Insert at position 0
   147→
   148→# Remove items from arrays
   149→tspec ts remove linker.args -nostdlib              # Remove by value
   150→tspec ts remove linker.args -static -pie           # Remove multiple by value
   151→tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args                   # Remove by index
   152→
   153→# Remove a field entirely
   154→tspec ts unset rustc.lto -p myapp                  # Remove scalar field
   155→tspec ts unset linker.args -t tspec-opt            # Remove array field
   156→
   157→# Backup and restore (byte-for-byte copies)
   158→tspec ts backup -p myapp                 # Backup tspec.ts.toml → tspec-001-abcd1234.ts.toml
   159→tspec ts backup -p myapp -t tspec-opt    # Backup tspec-opt.ts.toml
   160→tspec ts restore -t t1-001-abcd1234      # Restore t1.ts.toml from backup
   161→```
   162→
   163→Backups are valid spec files and can be used directly with `-t`.
   164→
   165→`ts set`, `ts unset`, `ts add`, and `ts remove` use `toml_edit` for surgical editing — comments and formatting are preserved.
   166→`ts backup`, `ts restore`, and `ts new -f` use byte-for-byte file copy — comments are preserved exactly.
   167→
   168→### Supported keys
   169→
   170→Keys use two forms: `FIELD` for top-level fields (`panic`, `strip`) or `TABLE.FIELD` for nested fields (`rustc.lto`, `linker.args`).
   171→
   172→| Key | Type | Values |
   173→|-----|------|--------|
   174→| `panic` | scalar | `unwind`, `abort`, `immediate-abort` |
   175→| `strip` | scalar | `none`, `debuginfo`, `symbols` |
   176→| `cargo.profile` | scalar | `debug`, `release` |
   177→| `cargo.target_triple` | scalar | any string |
   178→| `cargo.target_json` | scalar | any path |
   179→| `cargo.target_dir` | scalar | any string (supports `{name}`, `{hash}`) |
   180→| `cargo.unstable` | array | e.g. `panic-immediate-abort` |
   181→| `rustc.opt_level` | scalar | `0`, `1`, `2`, `3`, `s`, `z` |
   182→| `rustc.panic` | scalar | `abort`, `unwind`, `immediate-abort` |
   183→| `rustc.lto` | scalar | `true`, `false` |
   184→| `rustc.codegen_units` | scalar | integer |
   185→| `rustc.build_std` | array | e.g. `core alloc` |
   186→| `rustc.flags` | array | e.g. `-Cforce-frame-pointers=yes` |
   187→| `linker.args` | array | e.g. `-static -nostdlib` |
   188→
   189→### Array operations
   190→
   191→Four orthogonal commands operate on arrays at two levels:
   192→
   193→| Level | Command | Purpose |
   194→|-------|---------|---------|
   195→| Field-level | `ts set` | Replace entire array with new values |
   196→| Field-level | `ts unset` | Remove the array field entirely |
   197→| Item-level | `ts add` | Append items (or insert at position with `-i`) |
   198→| Item-level | `ts remove` | Remove items by value (or by index with `-i`) |
   199→
   200→```bash
   201→tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib   # replace all with these
   202→tspec ts unset linker.args                   # clear the field
   203→tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections   # append (skips duplicates)
   204→tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles  # insert at position
   205→tspec ts remove linker.args -static          # remove by value
   206→tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args             # remove by index
   207→```
   208→
   209→Values starting with `-` work without quoting thanks to `allow_hyphen_values`.
   210→Use `--` as an escape hatch if a value collides with a flag like `-p`, `-t`, or `-i`.
   211→
   212→Note: Use `ts` as the subcommand (short for "tspec management").
   213→
   214→## Testing
   215→
   216→```bash
   217→tspec test -p tspec           # Run tspec tests
   218→tspec test -p tspec-build     # Run tspec-build tests
   219→```
   220→
   221→## Project Structure
   222→
   223→```
   224→tspec/                  # Workspace root (also the main tspec package)
   225→  Cargo.toml            # [workspace] + [package] — workspace with root package
   226→  src/
   227→    lib.rs              # Library root, exposes modules
   228→    main.rs             # Entry point, dispatch
   229→    cli.rs              # Clap CLI definitions
   230→    types.rs            # Spec parameter types
   231→    tspec.rs            # Spec loading/saving/hashing
   232→    find_paths.rs       # Project/package/tspec/binary path discovery
   233→    workspace.rs        # Workspace package discovery
   234→    cargo_build.rs      # Build command + generated build.rs
   235→    run.rs              # Run command implementation
   236→    testing.rs          # Test command implementation
   237→    compare.rs          # Compare command (size comparison)
   238→    all.rs              # Batch operations (build_all, run_all, test_all, compare_all)
   239→    cmd/                # Command implementations (one file per command)
   240→    ts_cmd/             # Tspec management subcommands
   241→    binary.rs           # Binary operations (strip, size)
   242→  tests/
   243→    data/               # Test fixtures (TOML specs)
   244→    tspec_test.rs       # Integration tests
   245→  tspec-build/          # Library crate for build.rs integration
   246→    src/lib.rs          # Reads TSPEC_SPEC_FILE env var at build time
   247→  notes/                # Design docs and todo tracking
   248→```
   249→
   250→## Development
   251→
   252→See [notes/todo.md](notes/todo.md) for current tasks.
   253→
   254→### Verification
   255→
   256→```bash
   257→tspec test -p tspec
   258→tspec test -p tspec-build
   259→tspec clippy
   260→tspec fmt --check
   261→```
   262→
   263→## Origin
   264→
   265→Originally developed as `xt` within the [rlibc-x](https://github.com/user/rlibc-x) project, then extracted to a standalone tool. The git history was preserved using `git subtree split`.
   266→
   267→## License
   268→
   269→Licensed under either of
   270→
   271→- Apache License, Version 2.0 ([LICENSE-APACHE](LICENSE-APACHE) or http://apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0)
   272→- MIT license ([LICENSE-MIT](LICENSE-MIT) or http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
   273→

   275→
   276→Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted
   277→for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall
   278→be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.

file.content:
# tspec - Translation Spec Build System

A spec-driven build system for Rust that wraps cargo with configurable target triples, compiler flags, and linker options. Each tspec applies to a Cargo **package** — the unit with a `Cargo.toml`. If different crates need different compilation settings, they should be in separate packages.

**Status:** Active development. Works with both workspaces and single-package projects, Plain Old Packages (POPs).

## Installation

```bash
cargo install --path .
```

Or run directly:
```bash
cargo run -- build
```

## Usage

```bash
tspec build                                # Build current package (or all in workspace) with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build -p myapp                       # Build specific package with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build myapp                          # Same, using positional argument
tspec build .                              # Build the package in current directory
tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt          # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt.ts.toml  # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec build -p myapp -r -s                 # Build release, strip symbols with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec run -p myapp                         # Build and run with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec test -p myapp                        # Build and test with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build -w                             # Build all packages (even from inside a package dir)
tspec compare -p myapp                     # Compare binary sizes for a package
tspec compare -p myapp -t *.ts.toml        # Compare using shell-expanded glob
tspec compare                              # Compare all packages (workspace mode)
tspec compare -w                           # Force workspace mode from inside a package
tspec compare -w -f                        # Workspace mode, stop on first failure
```

The `-p` flag or positional argument specifies a package by name or path (defaults to current directory if in a package, otherwise all packages). Paths like `.` are resolved to the actual cargo package name. At a pure workspace root (no `[package]`), `.` means "all packages."
Use `-w, --workspace` to force all-packages mode even when inside a package directory.
The `-t` flag selects a tspec file; if omitted and `tspec.ts.toml` exists, it's used automatically.

**Note on `cmd` vs `cmd .`:** For passthrough commands (clean, clippy, fmt), `tspec cmd` passes no `-p` to cargo (operates on everything), while `tspec cmd .` resolves to `cargo cmd -p <name>` (package-specific). The difference is most visible with `clean`: `cargo clean` removes all of target/ while `cargo clean -p <name>` leaves shared metadata files. This matches cargo's own behavior. Use `tspec clean` or `tspec clean -w` for a full clean.

## tspec Files

Translation specs are TOML files (conventionally `*.ts.toml`) that configure builds:

```toml
# tspec.ts.toml - all supported fields shown

# Top-level high-level options (expand to lower-level cargo/rustc flags)
panic = "abort"                            # "unwind" (default), "abort", "immediate-abort" (nightly)
strip = "symbols"                          # "none" (default), "debuginfo", "symbols"

[cargo]
profile = "release"                        # "debug" (default), "release"
target_triple = "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl"
target_json = "path/to/custom-target.json" # custom target spec (auto-adds -Z json-target-spec)
unstable = ["panic-immediate-abort"]       # -Z flags (nightly only)
target_dir = "{name}"                      # per-spec target dir; supports {name} and {hash} placeholders

[rustc]
opt_level = "z"                            # "0", "1", "2", "3", "s", "z"
panic = "abort"                            # "abort", "unwind", "immediate-abort" (prefer top-level panic)
lto = true
codegen_units = 1
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]              # crates to rebuild with -Z build-std (nightly)
flags = ["-C", "relocation-model=static"]  # raw rustc flags passed through

[linker]
args = ["-static", "-nostartfiles"]

[linker.version_script]                    # symbol visibility control (enables --gc-sections)
global = ["_start"]                        # symbols to keep
local = "*"                                # default: "*" (hide everything else)
```

The top-level `panic` sets both cargo `-Z` and rustc `-C` flags automatically. If both
top-level `panic` and `rustc.panic` are set, both are applied (prefer one or the other).

### Key Concepts

- **One tspec per package** - A tspec applies to all crates (targets) within a Cargo package. For per-crate control, use separate packages in a workspace.
- **tspec.ts.toml is optional** - Packages without one get plain `cargo build/test`
- **Generated build.rs** - tspec generates temporary build.rs for scoped linker flags
- **Spec comparison** - Compare binary sizes across different specs; always shows both `cargo --release` and `cargo --release-strip` baselines. Supports `-w` for all-packages mode — per-package tables are collected and printed together at the end. With a single package, only its comparison table is shown

### How Linker Flags Work

tspec generates a temporary `build.rs` to apply linker flags with binary-scoped directives:

```rust
// Generated by tspec - deleted after build
fn main() {
    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-static");
    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-nostdlib");
}
```

This is necessary because RUSTFLAGS affects ALL compilations (including dependency
build scripts), causing crashes with flags like `-nostartfiles`. The generated
build.rs scopes flags to just the binary.

## tspec Management (ts subcommand)

Manage spec files without manual TOML editing. All commands that modify files preserve comments and formatting.

| Command | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| `ts list` | List tspec files found in the workspace or a specific package |
| `ts show` | Display the TOML contents of a tspec file |
| `ts hash` | Print the content hash (used in backup filenames) of a tspec |
| `ts new` | Create a new tspec with defaults, or copy an existing one with `-f` (byte-for-byte) |
| `ts set` | Set a scalar value or replace an entire array |
| `ts unset` | Remove a field (scalar or array) from a tspec entirely |
| `ts add` | Add items to an array field (append or insert at position) |
| `ts remove` | Remove items from an array field (by value or by index) |
| `ts backup` | Create a versioned backup copy (`name-NNN-hash.ts.toml`) |
| `ts restore` | Restore a tspec by copying a versioned backup back to its original name |

```bash
# List / show / hash
tspec ts list                            # List all tspec files
tspec ts list -p myapp                   # List tspec files for a package
tspec ts show -p myapp                   # Show all tspec contents
tspec ts show -p myapp -t tspec-opt      # Show specific tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec ts hash -p myapp                   # Show content hash of tspec.ts.toml

# Create new tspec files
tspec ts new -p myapp                    # Create tspec.ts.toml with defaults
tspec ts new experiment -p myapp         # Create experiment.ts.toml
tspec ts new opt2 -p myapp -f tspec-opt  # Copy from existing spec (byte-for-byte)

# Set scalar values
tspec ts set strip symbols -p myapp              # Set a scalar field
tspec ts set rustc.lto true -t tspec-opt         # Set in a specific tspec
tspec ts set cargo.profile release               # No quoting needed

# Set (replace) entire arrays — each element is a separate arg
tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib        # Replace array
tspec ts set rustc.build_std core alloc           # Replace array

# Add items to arrays (append by default)
tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections        # Append one item
tspec ts add linker.args -nostdlib -pie            # Append multiple items
tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles        # Insert at position 0

# Remove items from arrays
tspec ts remove linker.args -nostdlib              # Remove by value
tspec ts remove linker.args -static -pie           # Remove multiple by value
tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args                   # Remove by index

# Remove a field entirely
tspec ts unset rustc.lto -p myapp                  # Remove scalar field
tspec ts unset linker.args -t tspec-opt            # Remove array field

# Backup and restore (byte-for-byte copies)
tspec ts backup -p myapp                 # Backup tspec.ts.toml → tspec-001-abcd1234.ts.toml
tspec ts backup -p myapp -t tspec-opt    # Backup tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec ts restore -t t1-001-abcd1234      # Restore t1.ts.toml from backup
```

Backups are valid spec files and can be used directly with `-t`.

`ts set`, `ts unset`, `ts add`, and `ts remove` use `toml_edit` for surgical editing — comments and formatting are preserved.
`ts backup`, `ts restore`, and `ts new -f` use byte-for-byte file copy — comments are preserved exactly.

### Supported keys

Keys use two forms: `FIELD` for top-level fields (`panic`, `strip`) or `TABLE.FIELD` for nested fields (`rustc.lto`, `linker.args`).

| Key | Type | Values |
|-----|------|--------|
| `panic` | scalar | `unwind`, `abort`, `immediate-abort` |
| `strip` | scalar | `none`, `debuginfo`, `symbols` |
| `cargo.profile` | scalar | `debug`, `release` |
| `cargo.target_triple` | scalar | any string |
| `cargo.target_json` | scalar | any path |
| `cargo.target_dir` | scalar | any string (supports `{name}`, `{hash}`) |
| `cargo.unstable` | array | e.g. `panic-immediate-abort` |
| `rustc.opt_level` | scalar | `0`, `1`, `2`, `3`, `s`, `z` |
| `rustc.panic` | scalar | `abort`, `unwind`, `immediate-abort` |
| `rustc.lto` | scalar | `true`, `false` |
| `rustc.codegen_units` | scalar | integer |
| `rustc.build_std` | array | e.g. `core alloc` |
| `rustc.flags` | array | e.g. `-Cforce-frame-pointers=yes` |
| `linker.args` | array | e.g. `-static -nostdlib` |

### Array operations

Four orthogonal commands operate on arrays at two levels:

| Level | Command | Purpose |
|-------|---------|---------|
| Field-level | `ts set` | Replace entire array with new values |
| Field-level | `ts unset` | Remove the array field entirely |
| Item-level | `ts add` | Append items (or insert at position with `-i`) |
| Item-level | `ts remove` | Remove items by value (or by index with `-i`) |

```bash
tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib   # replace all with these
tspec ts unset linker.args                   # clear the field
tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections   # append (skips duplicates)
tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles  # insert at position
tspec ts remove linker.args -static          # remove by value
tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args             # remove by index
```

Values starting with `-` work without quoting thanks to `allow_hyphen_values`.
Use `--` as an escape hatch if a value collides with a flag like `-p`, `-t`, or `-i`.

Note: Use `ts` as the subcommand (short for "tspec management").

## Testing

```bash
tspec test -p tspec           # Run tspec tests
tspec test -p tspec-build     # Run tspec-build tests
```

## Project Structure

```
tspec/                  # Workspace root (also the main tspec package)
  Cargo.toml            # [workspace] + [package] — workspace with root package
  src/
    lib.rs              # Library root, exposes modules
    main.rs             # Entry point, dispatch
    cli.rs              # Clap CLI definitions
    types.rs            # Spec parameter types
    tspec.rs            # Spec loading/saving/hashing
    find_paths.rs       # Project/package/tspec/binary path discovery
    workspace.rs        # Workspace package discovery
    cargo_build.rs      # Build command + generated build.rs
    run.rs              # Run command implementation
    testing.rs          # Test command implementation
    compare.rs          # Compare command (size comparison)
    all.rs              # Batch operations (build_all, run_all, test_all, compare_all)
    cmd/                # Command implementations (one file per command)
    ts_cmd/             # Tspec management subcommands
    binary.rs           # Binary operations (strip, size)
  tests/
    data/               # Test fixtures (TOML specs)
    tspec_test.rs       # Integration tests
  tspec-build/          # Library crate for build.rs integration
    src/lib.rs          # Reads TSPEC_SPEC_FILE env var at build time
  notes/                # Design docs and todo tracking
```

## Development

See [notes/todo.md](notes/todo.md) for current tasks.

### Verification

```bash
tspec test -p tspec
tspec test -p tspec-build
tspec clippy
tspec fmt --check
```

## Origin

Originally developed as `xt` within the [rlibc-x](https://github.com/user/rlibc-x) project, then extracted to a standalone tool. The git history was preserved using `git subtree split`.

## License

- MIT license ([LICENSE-MIT](LICENSE-MIT) or http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)

for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall
be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# tspec - Translation Spec Build System

A spec-driven build system for Rust that wraps cargo with configurable target triples, compiler flags, and linker options. Each tspec applies to a Cargo **package** — the unit with a `Cargo.toml`. If different crates need different compilation settings, they should be in separate packages.

**Status:** Active development. Works with both workspaces and single-package projects, Plain Old Packages (POPs).

## Installation

```bash
cargo install --path .
```

Or run directly:
```bash
cargo run -- build
```

## Usage

```bash
tspec build                                # Build current package (or all in workspace) with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build -p myapp                       # Build specific package with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build myapp                          # Same, using positional argument
tspec build .                              # Build the package in current directory
tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt          # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec build -p myapp -t tspec-opt.ts.toml  # Build with alternative spec tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec build -p myapp -r -s                 # Build release, strip symbols with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec run -p myapp                         # Build and run with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec test -p myapp                        # Build and test with tspec.ts.toml if present
tspec build -w                             # Build all packages (even from inside a package dir)
tspec compare -p myapp                     # Compare binary sizes for a package
tspec compare -p myapp -t *.ts.toml        # Compare using shell-expanded glob
tspec compare                              # Compare all packages (workspace mode)
tspec compare -w                           # Force workspace mode from inside a package
tspec compare -w -f                        # Workspace mode, stop on first failure
```

The `-p` flag or positional argument specifies a package by name or path (defaults to current directory if in a package, otherwise all packages). Paths like `.` are resolved to the actual cargo package name. At a pure workspace root (no `[package]`), `.` means "all packages."
Use `-w, --workspace` to force all-packages mode even when inside a package directory.
The `-t` flag selects a tspec file; if omitted and `tspec.ts.toml` exists, it's used automatically.

**Note on `cmd` vs `cmd .`:** For passthrough commands (clean, clippy, fmt), `tspec cmd` passes no `-p` to cargo (operates on everything), while `tspec cmd .` resolves to `cargo cmd -p <name>` (package-specific). The difference is most visible with `clean`: `cargo clean` removes all of target/ while `cargo clean -p <name>` leaves shared metadata files. This matches cargo's own behavior. Use `tspec clean` or `tspec clean -w` for a full clean.

## tspec Files

Translation specs are TOML files (conventionally `*.ts.toml`) that configure builds:

```toml
# tspec.ts.toml - all supported fields shown

# Top-level high-level options (expand to lower-level cargo/rustc flags)
panic = "abort"                            # "unwind" (default), "abort", "immediate-abort" (nightly)
strip = "symbols"                          # "none" (default), "debuginfo", "symbols"

[cargo]
profile = "release"                        # "debug" (default), "release"
target_triple = "x86_64-unknown-linux-musl"
target_json = "path/to/custom-target.json" # custom target spec (auto-adds -Z json-target-spec)
unstable = ["panic-immediate-abort"]       # -Z flags (nightly only)
target_dir = "{name}"                      # per-spec target dir; supports {name} and {hash} placeholders

[rustc]
opt_level = "z"                            # "0", "1", "2", "3", "s", "z"
panic = "abort"                            # "abort", "unwind", "immediate-abort" (prefer top-level panic)
lto = true
codegen_units = 1
build_std = ["core", "alloc"]              # crates to rebuild with -Z build-std (nightly)
flags = ["-C", "relocation-model=static"]  # raw rustc flags passed through

[linker]
args = ["-static", "-nostartfiles"]

[linker.version_script]                    # symbol visibility control (enables --gc-sections)
global = ["_start"]                        # symbols to keep
local = "*"                                # default: "*" (hide everything else)
```

The top-level `panic` sets both cargo `-Z` and rustc `-C` flags automatically. If both
top-level `panic` and `rustc.panic` are set, both are applied (prefer one or the other).

### Key Concepts

- **One tspec per package** - A tspec applies to all crates (targets) within a Cargo package. For per-crate control, use separate packages in a workspace.
- **tspec.ts.toml is optional** - Packages without one get plain `cargo build/test`
- **Generated build.rs** - tspec generates temporary build.rs for scoped linker flags
- **Spec comparison** - Compare binary sizes across different specs; always shows both `cargo --release` and `cargo --release-strip` baselines. Supports `-w` for all-packages mode — per-package tables are collected and printed together at the end. With a single package, only its comparison table is shown

### How Linker Flags Work

tspec generates a temporary `build.rs` to apply linker flags with binary-scoped directives:

```rust
// Generated by tspec - deleted after build
fn main() {
    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-static");
    println!("cargo:rustc-link-arg-bin=myapp=-nostdlib");
}
```

This is necessary because RUSTFLAGS affects ALL compilations (including dependency
build scripts), causing crashes with flags like `-nostartfiles`. The generated
build.rs scopes flags to just the binary.

## tspec Management (ts subcommand)

Manage spec files without manual TOML editing. All commands that modify files preserve comments and formatting.

| Command | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| `ts list` | List tspec files found in the workspace or a specific package |
| `ts show` | Display the TOML contents of a tspec file |
| `ts hash` | Print the content hash (used in backup filenames) of a tspec |
| `ts new` | Create a new tspec with defaults, or copy an existing one with `-f` (byte-for-byte) |
| `ts set` | Set a scalar value or replace an entire array |
| `ts unset` | Remove a field (scalar or array) from a tspec entirely |
| `ts add` | Add items to an array field (append or insert at position) |
| `ts remove` | Remove items from an array field (by value or by index) |
| `ts backup` | Create a versioned backup copy (`name-NNN-hash.ts.toml`) |
| `ts restore` | Restore a tspec by copying a versioned backup back to its original name |

```bash
# List / show / hash
tspec ts list                            # List all tspec files
tspec ts list -p myapp                   # List tspec files for a package
tspec ts show -p myapp                   # Show all tspec contents
tspec ts show -p myapp -t tspec-opt      # Show specific tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec ts hash -p myapp                   # Show content hash of tspec.ts.toml

# Create new tspec files
tspec ts new -p myapp                    # Create tspec.ts.toml with defaults
tspec ts new experiment -p myapp         # Create experiment.ts.toml
tspec ts new opt2 -p myapp -f tspec-opt  # Copy from existing spec (byte-for-byte)

# Set scalar values
tspec ts set strip symbols -p myapp              # Set a scalar field
tspec ts set rustc.lto true -t tspec-opt         # Set in a specific tspec
tspec ts set cargo.profile release               # No quoting needed

# Set (replace) entire arrays — each element is a separate arg
tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib        # Replace array
tspec ts set rustc.build_std core alloc           # Replace array

# Add items to arrays (append by default)
tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections        # Append one item
tspec ts add linker.args -nostdlib -pie            # Append multiple items
tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles        # Insert at position 0

# Remove items from arrays
tspec ts remove linker.args -nostdlib              # Remove by value
tspec ts remove linker.args -static -pie           # Remove multiple by value
tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args                   # Remove by index

# Remove a field entirely
tspec ts unset rustc.lto -p myapp                  # Remove scalar field
tspec ts unset linker.args -t tspec-opt            # Remove array field

# Backup and restore (byte-for-byte copies)
tspec ts backup -p myapp                 # Backup tspec.ts.toml → tspec-001-abcd1234.ts.toml
tspec ts backup -p myapp -t tspec-opt    # Backup tspec-opt.ts.toml
tspec ts restore -t t1-001-abcd1234      # Restore t1.ts.toml from backup
```

Backups are valid spec files and can be used directly with `-t`.

`ts set`, `ts unset`, `ts add`, and `ts remove` use `toml_edit` for surgical editing — comments and formatting are preserved.
`ts backup`, `ts restore`, and `ts new -f` use byte-for-byte file copy — comments are preserved exactly.

### Supported keys

Keys use two forms: `FIELD` for top-level fields (`panic`, `strip`) or `TABLE.FIELD` for nested fields (`rustc.lto`, `linker.args`).

| Key | Type | Values |
|-----|------|--------|
| `panic` | scalar | `unwind`, `abort`, `immediate-abort` |
| `strip` | scalar | `none`, `debuginfo`, `symbols` |
| `cargo.profile` | scalar | `debug`, `release` |
| `cargo.target_triple` | scalar | any string |
| `cargo.target_json` | scalar | any path |
| `cargo.target_dir` | scalar | any string (supports `{name}`, `{hash}`) |
| `cargo.unstable` | array | e.g. `panic-immediate-abort` |
| `rustc.opt_level` | scalar | `0`, `1`, `2`, `3`, `s`, `z` |
| `rustc.panic` | scalar | `abort`, `unwind`, `immediate-abort` |
| `rustc.lto` | scalar | `true`, `false` |
| `rustc.codegen_units` | scalar | integer |
| `rustc.build_std` | array | e.g. `core alloc` |
| `rustc.flags` | array | e.g. `-Cforce-frame-pointers=yes` |
| `linker.args` | array | e.g. `-static -nostdlib` |

### Array operations

Four orthogonal commands operate on arrays at two levels:

| Level | Command | Purpose |
|-------|---------|---------|
| Field-level | `ts set` | Replace entire array with new values |
| Field-level | `ts unset` | Remove the array field entirely |
| Item-level | `ts add` | Append items (or insert at position with `-i`) |
| Item-level | `ts remove` | Remove items by value (or by index with `-i`) |

```bash
tspec ts set linker.args -static -nostdlib   # replace all with these
tspec ts unset linker.args                   # clear the field
tspec ts add linker.args -Wl,--gc-sections   # append (skips duplicates)
tspec ts add -i 0 linker.args -nostartfiles  # insert at position
tspec ts remove linker.args -static          # remove by value
tspec ts remove -i 2 linker.args             # remove by index
```

Values starting with `-` work without quoting thanks to `allow_hyphen_values`.
Use `--` as an escape hatch if a value collides with a flag like `-p`, `-t`, or `-i`.

Note: Use `ts` as the subcommand (short for "tspec management").

## Testing

```bash
tspec test -p tspec           # Run tspec tests
tspec test -p tspec-build     # Run tspec-build tests
```

## Project Structure

```
tspec/                  # Workspace root (also the main tspec package)
  Cargo.toml            # [workspace] + [package] — workspace with root package
  src/
    lib.rs              # Library root, exposes modules
    main.rs             # Entry point, dispatch
    cli.rs              # Clap CLI definitions
    types.rs            # Spec parameter types
    tspec.rs            # Spec loading/saving/hashing
    find_paths.rs       # Project/package/tspec/binary path discovery
    workspace.rs        # Workspace package discovery
    cargo_build.rs      # Build command + generated build.rs
    run.rs              # Run command implementation
    testing.rs          # Test command implementation
    compare.rs          # Compare command (size comparison)
    all.rs              # Batch operations (build_all, run_all, test_all, compare_all)
    cmd/                # Command implementations (one file per command)
    ts_cmd/             # Tspec management subcommands
    binary.rs           # Binary operations (strip, size)
  tests/
    data/               # Test fixtures (TOML specs)
    tspec_test.rs       # Integration tests
  tspec-build/          # Library crate for build.rs integration
    src/lib.rs          # Reads TSPEC_SPEC_FILE env var at build time
  notes/                # Design docs and todo tracking
```

## Development

See [notes/todo.md](notes/todo.md) for current tasks.

### Verification

```bash
tspec test -p tspec
tspec test -p tspec-build
tspec clippy
tspec fmt --check
```

Originally developed as `xt` within the [rlibc-x](https://github.com/user/rlibc-x) project, then extracted to a standalone tool. The git history was preserved using `git subtree split`.
